text:
Two issues

1: Reduced gas prices due to lower oil prices will make gas powered cars cheaper, which will taper off demand for EVs
2: You also assume that with cheaper oil, that demand would fall, while in reality other industries [Chemical, Big Phrama, Electrical, Plastics, Cosmetic] would pick up the slack when they are presented with very very cheap feedstock and energy.

This is also assuming you can get past the issue that there isnt an unlimited supply of lithium in the world, and that with increased demand on the limited supply will cause prices to jump [unlike oil, which can be created basicly everywhere and is very flexiable on where it can be found, lithium can only be found in a few select locations in the world with the right climates and right soil, and Sodium batteries are not amazing either, you cant get around lithium with that].

All in all, while EVs very well could tap down oil growth, its unlikely to fall more so than flat line, just due to the fact that there are a lot of other industries that would jump at the ability to get cheap oil, making a price floor. Plus its nearly impossible [or i should say impratical] to go 100% renewable with out things like nuclear energy or fusion [which the former is hated on unfairly due to irrational fears of nuclear bombs and two accidents [that in the grand scale of things, where not that bad] and the later is 30 years away yesterday, 30 years away today, 30 years away tomrrow and 30 years away in 30 years time], so your going to likely still have a huge demand for base load oil or natural gas, which would only grow with cheap energy.

Again EVs can likely tap down the growth in oil, but not eliminate it [look at coal for example, after decades of protests aginst it and governments trying to reduce its use world wide, we are now only barely reaching peak coal in 2018/2019, and coal has a lot less uses than oil does.] More than likely this "Neo-Peak Oil" will only come around when oil either truely starts running out [or the cost to extract it rises way to high] or some breakthrough that no one can see happens [unlikely]. 

But this is only coming from a Chemical Engineering degree student at Michigan Tech who is also getting a minor degree in "Petro-Chemicals and Polymers" and "geology", so what do I know [A lot on this in fact].

text: Because natural gas is so cheap due to fracking and deep water drilling, it's likely that US electric power will continue to be generated using fossil fuels.  (In 2017, the percentage of US electricity generated using fossil fuels was 63%.)  So, if electric vehicles are evenly distributed around the US, they will essentially be fossil fuel powered vehicles.  But this will be a very inefficient use of fossil fuels.  Fossil fuels will be burned at the utility plants, where it will be converted into electricity.  Then it will be transmitted to communities during which energy losses will occur.  Then it will be distributed to homes during which energy losses will occur.  Then it will be used to charge your EV's battery, during which more energy losses will occur.  So, if you are going to power your vehicle using fossil fuels anyway, it's much more efficient just to use a fossil fuel consuming engine.

text:
Well . . .  most of that is not true.  I mean the supposed "massive" amount of Electricity that EVs use.  

We can do the math, if you like -- but really EVs use just a fraction of the Energy that ICEs (Internal Combustion Engines) use to produce the same results.  

In the US we have Surplus Electricity, so it is not even a real concern -- I do modeling for the US Grid -- I do not do modeling for the UK -- but it looks like you have Big Wind ahead that can carry much of it.  No Nukes Required. :)

text:
Electric primary propulsion (controller, motor and transmission, ignoring the source of electricity) is too efficient and simple to ignore. Electric drivetrain production costs are also already on par with their combustion equivalents, if you don't take the batteries into account. However, that was also the case with early 20th century electric cars, and they were taken out by bad battery technology and actions of a smaller oil industry. Today, we have only 0,1 % of electric cars, versus almost 40% 110 years ago. Have in mind the oil industry is now much more powerful, and is buying out all energy storage technologies and suppressing them, lowering the chances of a disruptive battery technology reaching the market.

My guess for the future is that electric cars will remain costing about 60% more than their conventional counterparts, and battery energy density will remain on it's current trend, taking about 10 years to double. However, in the near future, someone with ties with the oil industry will release some sort of fuel dependent electric generator (direct fuel/hydrogen fuel cells, microturbine, etc.), that will give these new "electric" cars a fuel economy of about 70 MPG (or lower depending on the economy of hybrid cars of the time).

author: Phil Timmons

text: @Phil: With a 220watt outlet, how many miles of driving do I get with every hour of charging?
author: mrpmj00

text:
mrpmj00¬† -- let me be sure what you are asking?   When you say 220 "watt" outlet -- you probably mean a 220 Volt (typical European) -- (or 240 Volt (US))?

And then if that is what you are asking -- the miles vary by the AMPS of the outlet, and the car (EV), itself.  

So some typical numbers are:   

For someone "Cheap" poor-boy like me with a Chevy Volt -- a 240 Volt, 20 Amp outlet will charge my Volt to go 40 miles in about 4 hours.  That is among the lower performers of the industry -- but it is intended for "poor(er)" folk like me.

For a typical Tesla buyer -- with an X or an S -- if they use their mobile plug -- 240 Volt, 50 Amps -- they get about 29 Miles per hour of charge.

For a Tesla with home Wall Charger -- we directly wire these to a Circuit Breaker in the panel -- again with a Tesla X or Tesla S,  they get about 50 to 60 Miles per hour of charge. 

I think the numbers on the Model 3(s) are about 50% faster or 50% further (smaller, lighter car), but have not played with those yet to confirm.  

The commercial site "super-chargers" are much faster -- but that is not what you were asking, right?

author: William Edstrom

text:
Obvious flaws...
1. A oil usage still involves ships, trucks, aircraft, etc. Replacing 1% of cars will electric cars won't necessarily reduce overall oil rates.
2. Even if you replaced 1% of current cars, developed countries are still buying more cars -- so this won't work unless you get China, India, and Africa do buy electric.
3. You are also assuming that existing cars will be replaced by electrics. Sorry... average new car now lasts 20+ years. Anyone buying a non-electric today isn't going to replace it in overall numbers for at least 20 years.
4. Even if you replaced millions of cars with electric vehicles... that wouldn't necessarily mean oil would go down. Almost no modern country has a surplus of renewable energy. We are out of rivers to dam, solar and wind are too expensive, etc. That means we are either going nuclear (which takes 20+ years to get reactors build), coal (hard to get coal plants built in developed countries these days), gas, or oil. So... we could easily end up burning oil to make all that needed electricity.
5. We are assuming that electric car production isn't otherwise limited. Reality... the rare metals in current car batteries means huge amounts of energy to make those batteries and they may actually be more limited than oil (by a far margin).

text: this problem of this article is that oil powers a lot more than cars. The batteries in the electric cars are made with rare metals mined using diesel machines then shipped using diesel trucks and ships to be refined and manufactured in factories that use regular power station power (mostly still fossil fuel at this time) then combined with thousands of components, some of which are made with oil derivative materials in order to be made into an electric car to plug into the mains supply (again mostly fossil fuel at this time in most countries). Then there is the lifespan of the batteries, which is quite short which means constant remanufacture of these cells. Its not a fix and its not as damaging for the oil industry as you might think. Besides the oil giants own a lot of the renewables market so they will be fine. Not saying it won‚Äôt cause an upset in the balance but i think a crash is a lot further away than 2023

text:
However, the crashing oil prices will be making the gasoline driven cars cheaper to operate, so the big increase of EV cars will be making them less economically viable for the end consumer. This will not be exactly a "snap" that breaks suddenly, but more like a race between the gasoline and electric cars with each having to outcompete other cost-wise. If the costs of manufacturing EV cars will not fall fast enough, the traditional cars can hold on longer than an S-curve would predict.

In addition massive EV adoption will be a huge problem for most countries - almost every country imposes various taxes on gasoline, that they do not on electricity. And with a possibility to generate you own, untaxable electricity from sun or wind, the governments will loose a lot of income from those 'transport taxes'. What is a serious problem, given how most of big economies are in debt right now. Unless we solve the world's debt problem first, the EV revolution might indirectly cause political and economical instability all over the world.

text:
The price per KW of those solar panels are dropping by about 5% a year.  That may not seem like much but over a decade that is a $24,000 system dropping to under $15,000.   The battery storage is also dropping each year but not quite at that same rate.  Gasoline, Oil, Coal, Natural gas, aren't consistently dropping at 5% a year.  Solar is eventually going to hit a price point where everything else is an expensive hassle and every roof that can have solar on it will have solar on it.   

New homes will be designed to have a maximum solar collection area, so instead of a 5KW system they will crank out a 20KW system.   It can be 118 degrees outside and the solar on your roof keeps your house down to 72 degrees.  

Peaker plants are already obsolete in California.  When they are most needed is the middle of the day light hours on hot summer days.  When the sun is being relentless.

text:
Today, most green technologies are targeted towards conscientious people, who are ready to sacrifice efficiency and money for the technology. 

For example, I could never afford an electric car (not even an hybrid) and I wouldn't be able to recharge the car. People buying electric cars right now are known as early adopters. 

Yet, the perspective is that electric cars will become more efficient, cheap, and could begin replacing thermal-explosion vehicles. This is when you'll start seeing more ordinary people buy the car, and it's the beginning of the S-curve. Basically, the cars are cheaper, more efficient, and don't require gas. (A typical family spends hundreds a month in gas). 

When this explosion occurs, the infrastructure for electric cars will become easily accessible, practical, and people will not see the difference between oil engines, and electric ones. (But as we said, I for example spend 50$/week on gas. So for a similar product, I'll choose the electric one). At this point we have an exponential explosion. 

Finally, we have the late adopters. Some people will try to hang to their gas cars, but it will become less and less practical. It's at this point that the market will saturate. Most people will have switched to electric cars. 

There are A LOT of examples of this happening in the past. Color TV for example, used to be expensive, required big screens, most TV shows didn't broadcast in color etc. But the technology got better, less expensive, and the color TV started flooding the market... etc.

text:
"Offshore drilling and fracking are making more fuel available" Yes and these methods are more difficult, more expensive, and arguably more destructive. This translates into $$$, which is what the point of peak oil theory was. Oil would get more expensive to pull from the ground so more and more methods will be created to avoid oil altogether, so the demand drops and te production drops to match.

Here's what we should do: We in the developed world should reduce our oil dependence as rapidly as possible while still producing at current rates. This way, we can export more and more oil to developing countries that still need it, and use the incoming funds to pay for infrastructure overhauls which can further reduce our dependence, and the process accelerates.

This is roughly how Norway does it. Their green energy and recycling infrastructure was funded in no small part by their oil exports to other european countries. It also helps fund their very generous welfare state, which the US would likely put into other areas such as roads, education, and universal health care while generally keeping the government less invasive than the Nordic model.

But in this way, we can reap the benefits of oil production, lead the world in alternative energy research, and pull the developing world closer to our level in the process, while still meeting climate change demands.

text:
Wayne Sproehnle No, gas FUMES are what go 'boom,' NOT the liquid itself.  Lithium, on the other hand, DOES, because, just like any other alkaline metal like sodium, it reacts with water in the air spontaneously.  Read some real science instead of gender studies, please.

Battery electrolytes are NOT recyclable, and end up filling millions of drums at toxic waste depots.  Only battery CASES are reused.  So batteries pollute FAR worse than petroleum does.  Why do you think EVs got the boot in the 70s, anyway?  Because of BATTERIES and their inherent unfriendliness to the environment.

Now, all those facts aside, who here can tell me where all the plastics, lubes, and solvents used worldwide will come from, IF oil is no longer sold?  You can't have batteries or advanced electronics or most medical equipment and so forth without oil.  Sorry, but this is crap of the highest order, from the same outfit that said real estate never crashes.

Its not about convenience, EV will never charge as fast as you can top up a tank. Maybe someone will successfully push through a battery quick-change scheme but I don't see it happening in foreseeable future.

text:
This video is now seriously outdated as far as the projections go.  by 2040 almost all new cars produced will be fully electric.  The only new vehicle production that will be gasoline or diesel will be military and most of them will be hybrid of some sort.  With a very very small market for offload type vehicles where charging stations just wont be available.

Most of this was made not only possible but likely by Elon Musk and his giga factory as well as the almost overwhelming success of the Tesla vehicle lines.  Government policies also push this harder and harder every year.  Part of it is environmental concern.  Part of it is the fact that their voting public wants its also mostly for environmental concern.  Yet possibly the biggest part of it is the fact that big oil has WAY to much influence over politics than any politician is comfortable with.  They are tired of being led around on a leash by big oil and they want it to stop.  A 20 year plan to do that probably sounds pretty good to any career politician.  This is no a conspiracy theory :).  Just common sense backed up by many public statements of politicians who were "railroaded" out of office by big oil because they wouldn't play ball.  For those that don't know the "railroad commission" is the government agency responsible for oil regulation in the USA.  Why there isn't an "oil commission" for such a massive part of our economy is just another layer of confusion to make it harder to people to see whats really going on with the policies in place.

Regardless of the motivations the world is about to have a massive shift towards electric and self driven vehicles.  China is actually leading the charge in that regard as it pertains to government policy while the United States now thx almost entirely to Elon Musk and his supporters is leading the charge commercially.  I have no doubt that one of the next 5 giga factories he says he will announce the locations of soon will be in China.  Once it is up and running then China will likely closely mirror the US progress towards replacing their vehicle fleets with fully electric.

Soon after electric and self driven cars prove themselves over gasoline vehicles for safety and fuel economy (how far you can drive for a given amount of money gas or electric) almost all other car manufacturers will follow suit and start developing their own versions of electric and self driven vehicles.  This is as inevitable as people putting light bulbs in their houses.  I'm sure there was a time when most people thought.  "Why would I need a light bulb.  I can just burn a candle for light".  Gasoline cars are the candle and its about to go out.

Don't get me wrong.  Oil production is in NO risk of "loosing the billions invested in it"  There will be enough of a tapering off period over several decades that the existing equipment which has been invested into the oil industry will basically be used up.  The only thing that will happen is that production of new oil related equipment will start to tapper off.  The industry will then lead towards producing replacement parts for a few years and finally the consolidated industry remaining will simply be significantly scaled down.

On the bright side because of the influx of electric cars into the fleet gasoline demand will soon reach a point where it begins to actually decline.  From this point on there will be no justifiable reason to increase the gasoline prices and we may even see them decrease before finding a gas pump to fill up at is as rare as an electric car charging station is now.  But we are talking 2030 at the earliest for all that.

People will lose their jobs and industries will shift.  Factories that once made oil rigs will start making wind turbines or solar panels.  Or more likely just the support structures for them.  It won't be the end of the world.  It won't even be a new world.  It will just change a little and so slowly that the most conservative of us can keep up.  So as they say in the hitchhikers guide to the galaxy... "DON"T PANIC"

text: There is one issue missing in this report; with the increase of the number of electric vehicles on the road, demand will also increase on electricity. Electricity is typically generated in Power plants which either burn fossil fuel or nuclear fuel, or it can come from environmentally friendly stations such as wind farms or hydro dams. The efficiency of a normal car at its best is ~18-20% while in fossil fuel power plants its close to ~55%. Switching to electric cars will, in my opinion, shift the burning of fossil fuel from cars to fossil fuel power plants with a better efficiency. The theory in this document will be true only in the case where electricity is being generated from a source other than fossil fuel.

text: Where do you think the electricity will come from to recharge the batteries for all of these electric cars?¬†¬† Plus the batteries will need replacing every 5 years¬† (at about 1/2 the cost of a new electric car).¬†¬† So built in obsolesce will give these vehicles a very short life span.¬†¬† Don't forget about the time it takes to recharge the battery, or the fire hazard from faulty Li-ion batteries.¬†¬† One possible solution could come from using NH3 (ie: liquefied ammonia gas) which¬†uses low pressure tanks, has a higher energy density than cryogenic hydrogen, and when burned, releases zero emissions.¬†¬†Plus the refuel time will be equal to using gasoline.¬† Minimum fire¬†hazard, as NH3 is lighter than air, so there is not a¬†concentrated liquid¬†fuel source to support combustion.¬†¬† Our current electrical power plants¬†could convert their¬†surplus electricity to NH3 and store it¬†in tanks feeding a pipeline distribution network, during off peak power demand.¬†¬† Or this stored NH3 could fuel gas turbines to add power to the Grid, when demand and prices are higher.¬†¬† A much more reliable energy source than Wind or Solar.¬†¬† NH3 is currently used for fertilizer in Agriculture.

author: zamazalotta

text:
You expect a certain amount of naivety from enthusiastic EV proponents (i'm one myself). 
But did you ever consider what the real world is run on outside of the gas/petrol car/truck. Three combustion engine industries unable to be converted to Electric because of a theoretical limit (never mind practical implementation). 
1) Aviation passenger and freight cargo, defence force aircraft.
2) Trucking/Freight vehicles, again defence force vehicles.
3) Power Stations - oil/petroleum fired
4) Plastics

The first two are a matter of power to weight ratio being too great to overcome. An electric motor efficiency cannot be greater than 98%. A battery storage system will have to wait until nano carbon tubes are a reality and we have a capacitor that stores enough for a 2 hour heavy payload flight - but by then we will have run out of oil, so moot point.

The third industrial application, which burns more than you would think, is common as backup generation in the first world, but in Asia it is common to be the primary means of electrical generation (Thailand is a major example). The other alternatives are just as messed up and significant cost which the governments certainly won't be spending to make a change they cannot see or benefit from.

But above and beyond these considerations is a huge primary reason the oil companies won't be going out of business anytime in the next 30 years...  The plastics industries!!!  where did you imagine plastic comes from ? Nearly half of the oil production globally goes to making the very parts you want to make your EV's out of, so they are nice and light. Carbon fibre is an especially petroleum concentrated derivative - both the fibres and resin.

So while I am agreeing with cars being electric, I don't foresee these other more important sectors dying off before oil does.

The alternative may be to have miniature depleted nuclear fuel based engines with short half-life ration sources that need refilling, so that no major bomb is created (accidentally or intentionally).

Happy for someone to disagree with the above, but would like a reasoned explanation other than troll-baiting.

The biggest issue with electric cars is charging time. The effect "range" of, for example the Toyota Camry 2017 is 400 miles in the city and 560 on the highway. With a fuel up time of less than 5 minutes to get a full tank.

Now compare that to electric cars. Where you have less range and longer wait to charge up. So you have to charge up more often and it all takes longer.

The fastest chargers are the Tesla Superchargers, which are only for Teslas. And they still are very slow.  Half an hour for 200 miles, that is weak. Everyone else has to charge for hours to reach 200 miles of driving.

And finally frequent fast charging leads to the battery losing it's maximum capacity. So after five years your "range" is 50% of what it was before.

text:
AFAIK the trouble with electric cars so far is the batteries- lithium ion/polymer is a great technology, but requires vast amounts of precious metals, and is way less energy dense compared to petroleum. So making them large enough to give any car decent range or power results in a very expensive slow car.

Hybrids seem like the obvious winner: Lightweight small batteries, able to charge and use petroleum fuel, can run the engine at its optimum rpm constantly, and still gets all of the transmission advantages attributed to electric cars such as regenerative braking and continuously variable torque/speed.

text:
We need 100% renewable energy sources, currently Li-ion isn't renewable not to mention it's only energy storage. If batteries weren't so ecologically damaging by heavy metal mining nor poorly recyclable then certainly batteries would be a good option. Li-ion batteries are a stop gap and a trading of one finite source for another.

Batteries are evolving but slowly, once the batteries, power storage, use quickly refillable and renewable electrolytes with more abundant renewable and recyclable materials then you may have something worth building large scale infrastructure around.
author: D Jaquith

text:
The problem right now is cost of the vehicles, life of the batteries, range anxiety, and access to charging and recharging, plus market considerations.

This codeveloper of the lithium ion battery has invented a new battery at 94 years old (not bad) that looks to be 3x more powerful, charges in minutes versus hours and has more cycles than the current batteries:

http://spectrum.ieee.org/energywise/energy/renewables/does-new-glass-battery-accelerate-the-end-of-oil

If this technology proves to be viable, this tech would fix the cost of owning an EV, the range anxiety, the weight/performance would improve, the charging issue would be fixed, but what does that leave?

Infrastructure still doesn't exist for apartment owners to charge their cars, for instance, but as long as supercharger stations could charge a car in a few minutes, and be developed fast enough to meet demand (a relatively easy thing to do) then all would be well. 

The other infrastructure component is supplying the energy grid with enough power. The utility companies would see a huge spike in power demands. Home owners could see a spike in their home energy bill. Something would need to rapidly change to accommodate this demand.

The other factor is simply interest in gasoline engines. With the price of gas plummeting the cost to drive a gasoline vehicle would become even cheaper, and many may prefer the sound and experience of running a ICE vehicle, especially sports car enthusiasts. And yet, at the same time, these enthusiasts will also be contending with electric sports cars that will easily out perform their ICE vehicle, so unless they are a purist, this tech will be disruptive to everyone.

text: I love electric cars. I'd like to own a Tesla if I could afford it.  But it seems to me what wasn't talked about was....... WHERE IS ALL THE ELECTRICITY GONNA COME FROM? Are we going to cover our planet with solar PV panels, or desecrate our hill ridges with wind turbines, or flood our beautiful valleys with hydro lakes. Perhaps we can crank up our oil and gas fired power stations or build more. The most economic way is to build more Fukushima's of course. The total economics of the EV must be considered and this not only includes the running of the vehicle and source of power but also needs to take into account the manufacture and disposal of its parts.  The toxic fallout from used batteries would be immense and recycling is not a foregone conclusion. Good article at slatedotcom -  ''If All U.S. Cars Suddenly Became Electric, How Much More Electricity Would We Need?'' The maths doesn't look pretty.   According to this study the US would require a 30% increase in power generation. That's a huge investment which I doubt President Trump will be making. It even appears that the EV is not so green when you look at the whole economics and environmental impact. It is fairly well known that an electric vehicle on the East Coast is actually more polluting than a gasoline car once the power generation is taken into account. These are all points to consider.

text: This seems to be an overly simplistic way of thinking about transportation and does not mention the thing that will really kill oil; self-drive cars. If people don't need to buy a car, but instead renting self-drive cars by the hour.¬†The number of cars that need to convert to electric and change the oil markets drops significantly. For example: if 10,000 car owners can share 5000 electric cars for daily activities and those cars still drive the same amount of miles,. They reduce the number of gallons oil would consume and increase gallons run on electric. This could be done without costing the end user the 80k for an electric self-drive vehicle. This video also doesn't take into account the possibility that people will use trains to cover large sections more quickly, or the possibility of cars being designed to only hold 1-2 people depending on the trip.

author: Nicolas Klarsfeld

text:
But where will the energy to charge the cars come from? The production of electricity to charge them will come mostly from the existing electricity infrastructure which is largely based on burning hydrocarbons, of which oil makes a major share. So even if all cars were to suddenly become electric you would at most reduce the consumption of oil by cars by some 50%. Even so the overall reduction would be far less as cars account for a relatively small share of oil consumption, the other major consumers being electricity production, industry, shipping and aviation.
Electrification of land transport will put a dent in oil consumption but not a major one.  If oil production is going to take a hit it will have to be by changes in other sectors than just cars and trucks.
author: Lister Dave

text: Most of the energy in cars is lost to heat. You push on the gas, than you break. In an electric car, most of this energy is conserved... So instead of loosing almost 99% of the energy, and using 1% to go forward. You use 80% of the energy to go forward. That's where the imbalance comes in.
author: Matthew Hemmings

text:
Regenerative braking does save considerable energy but more in the likes of 10-20% when averaged over typical driving conditions.
The energy lost to braking is in practice found to be much less than is lost in rolling resistance and aerodynamic drag for the typical average drive.
Going up and down steep winding roads is when regenerative braking really helps. The more typical highway or even city and town center driving benefits much less from regenerative braking.
It is no doubt a great thing to have but its impact on energy consumption is often highly over estimated.

text: A good documentary, but wrong on at least one point. After the S-curve takeoff, which will result in only about %25 of new cars being sold as pure EVs, the net result will be the USA becoming a net oil exporter, and changing our trade deficits from negative to positive, since the biggest contributor to trade deficits is foreign oil purchases.  This will be a bigger positive effect on the USA than any other country in the world, since we are the only ones that both produce huge quantities of oil but also use huge quantities. The biggest losers in the oil market are oil dependent nations such as Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Canada and others. Thus the biggest side effect is the acceleration of war and regime changes around the world as such countries loose their power to effectively bribe their populations into quiescence.

text:
A couple of corrections.
- China has more electric cars than Europe and the US combined. India probably have a lot of them too. Their governments aren't run by oil companies.
- Tesla plans to reach 500K cars per year a lot faster. I hope they succeed because I want a Model 3 too, and they have around 500K preorders to fulfill before I get a chance.
- EVs will take off much faster then the video expects. In a few years EVs will be much better than gas guzzlers in practically every way, including price. Modern internal combustion engines are insanely complex and therefore very expensive, mostly because emissions and fuel economy. And they will never be cheap again because of that. Electric engines on the other hand are very simple and cheap, and battery prices are dropping at an insane rate. Ranges are now comfortable, and charging networks are growing exponentially. People are more and more open to EVs, and those who tried them never look back. Also some cities may ban diesel cars as early as 2020. Because of these things demand will explode (the 500K Tesla Model 3 preorder is a clear sign of this). In developed countries a lot of people buy a new car every 3 to 5 years, and few people drive more than 10-15 years old ones in any decent country. So 50% EV by 2040 isn't a radical idea, I think it's a pessimistic prediction. It could easily be 90%.
- The price of oil is controlled by the US and Saudi Arabia by adjusting production rates, and by invading other oil rich countries. Prices dropped recently for two reasons. First, they wanted to hurt Russia, which depends heavily on it's oil export revenue. Second, they wanted to slow down the clean energy revolution by making natural gas a lot cheaper.

author: Supernaut

text:
If the electric car revolution is going to happen the cars in question will need some of today's modern features, specifically heated seats, cruise control, power windows/locks/mirrors, wireless key entry and locking, some level of space for at least 4 passengers and luggage, and above all at least a 300 mile range and recharging is going to have to come down to a 15-20min window: empty to full.
The 300 mile range is key because many families are one car households. This means the car needs to be available for everyday living, which equals 100-150miles a day, but it will also need to be capable of going the distance on family road trips. 300 miles in a 4-4h30min ride is very doable for many folks, but many don't really want to drive beyond that amount of time.
If cars get to the 300 mile range, recharge quickly, and be competitively priced [by this I mean within 2-3k dollars more at most], the S curve will occur, but not until those criteria are met.

text:
They are coming from the assumption that much of the electricity produce in the US is still coming from coal and the idea that cleaner renewable sources are still way off in the distance. This assumption is not true and shows Adam's lack of keeping up with the latest trends. 

Solar panels, predominantly for commercial use, are now a far cheaper source of electricity production than is coal. In fact panels are so cheap right now that many companies are selling older stock at a loss so they may increase production of the more efficient upgrades.

Additionally, the idea "we are all going to go out and get a new car more often" [I am paraphrasing there] is also a fallacy. Folks will go get a new electric once their current combustion engine vehicle dies and that is only if electrics end up being competitively priced. Once production gets going full tilt we may see combustion engine costs come down, with dealers having huge sales to get rid of archaic options.

He is right about the carbon costs of making electrics though. They are simply more painful on the front end, but the savings on the back end are extremely high. 

Add the carbon savings to the toppling of terrorist organizations like Exxon Mobile, the Koch brothers, the Saudi, Iranian, Russian empires, and the world at large will be a much safer, cleaner, freer, and happier place.

text: Actually, peak oil is very real - it has to be... think about it for a second. No new oil is being made, we're just extracting the crappiest leftovers only while prices are high. We certainly have reached peak cheap oil and fracking, tar sands, etc. only make economic sense when oil prices are high. But when oil prices are high, economies falter... and then the price drops, and fracking isn't viable. Rinse & repeat. Market volatility very nicely demonstrates how we're hitting the limits. Call it peak oil, or whatever, it's the same process.

+bla ba even at 100% coal electric cars would produce less pollution in as much as they are a minimum of 4X as energy efficient than ICE. ICE's produce more waste heat than they do forward motion per unit of fuel.

As for renewables not being competitive you're a long way behind the times. Both wind and solar producers are offering the cheapest electricity currently, signing long term power purchase agreements for  delivered kwh for less than it costs to get coal out of the ground. A new low happened in Dubai where a new solar plant signed a power deal for .$03 per kwh. The holy grail to make solar competitive was $1.00 per watt.  large scale solar is now 0.40 a watt and forecast to be  0.25 by 2020.

Add to that the potential synergy with large numbers of electric cars on the grid. Since the utilization of cars in the US is about 4% it means that most of the time their batteries could be available as grid storage.

CO^2 is released in the air(doesn't matter where from). What happens to the CO^2? Does the CO^2 stay in the air for millions, or billions of years? NO, see nature has a way of using CO^2 it is called photosynthesis. Photosynthesis is a process used by plants and other organisms to convert light energy, normally from the Sun, into chemical energy that can be later released to fuel the organisms' activities (energy transformation). Fuel from photosynthesis can be reused as a energy.

When was the last time you drank something with soda water in it? Do you die from all the emissions from the soda water? Because soda water has water and CO^2 in it, and that is the same emissions from natural gas.

As for the batteries, not to worry,¬†lithium is recyclable and the Gigaplant in Nevada is designed to facilitate that process but they can also use the batteries¬†as backup storage or primary storage¬†for off grid applications after their usable lifespan is over. The Tesla Powerwall is simply that and is currently available. For comparison, the Powerwall is available with a 10Kw battery and a Nissan Leaf has a 24 Kw.¬†The cost to just refine crude oil into gasoline takes as much electricity as it does to power an electric car 20 miles. This is before it's trucked from the distillery to the gas station. Where¬†does that electricity come from? Don't get me started on fuel cells. To complete the comparison in all fairness, you should really consider the entire impact of manufacturing, delivery, recycling, etc for both means of transportation. I think you'll find the electric car is so far ahead we will look back and wonder why it took so long to get here. And the real bonus is you'll never see a check engine light again.

author: Dangerous Dingo

text:
Battery replacements won't be "cheap", but considering how long an electric car should last with so few moving parts, it's almost the only thing you'd ever need to replace over the mid to long range timeframe of owning one.

Tesla is aiming for a conservative estimate of $100/kWh of battery capacity with their gigafactory, and LG is already around $120/kWh today. So if you look at, say, a Chevy Volt with an 18kWh battery, you're talking about a replacement cost of about $2,500 - $3,500 including markup and labor. A Nissan Leaf has a 36kWh battery, which would come in at around $4,500. Even a top of the line, $153,000 Tesla Model S/X P100D you'd be looking at around $12,000 for a brand new battery.

Compare that with an engine or transmission in any newer vehicle and you're right in line with buying a high mileage gas powered car of equivalent market segment (A $150k Mercedes engine would cost around the same as a Tesla Model S/X battery, a Chevy Volt battery would be in line with something like a Honda Civic engine, etc.)‚Äî something lots of poor people do already.

Given that the cost will only come down even further as demand taps economies of scale, and you're talking about the wholesale replacement of gas-powered personal transportation in the next 20 years. Especially if you factor in the maintenance cost with owning an electric car. Oil changes every 3,000 miles? Gone. Belts and filters? Non-existant. Your ownership costs will amount to tires, wipers, and light bulbs, and even light bulbs are going away with the shift to LED lighting.

text:
Eventual electrification of cars is inevitable due to the constant need for ever higher efficiency; combustion engine efficiency is only 15 - 35% compared to at least 75% for an electric motor.
They've been doing everything under the sun to squeeze more efficiency from combustion engines (start-stop, valve timing, more valves, lighter alloys, direct injection, turbo chargers, improved aerodynamics etc etc) but it just seems like polishing a turd over and over again and there will only be diminishing returns while making the engine ever more complex.

Hybrids are the first stages of this change over, they were forced to do this to get more efficiency

text:
Electric cars aren't here to stop CO2 emissions. Well, not directly. They're here to increase fuel efficiency, since ICE energy efficiency is around 30% while electric machines have efficiency over 80%. If we take into account oil-powered plants and transmission losses however, electric machines are pretty much on par with ICE.

My point is that as electric cars replace ICE cars, power stations will move to the more plentiful and cheaper oil.

text:
The advancements in batteries that have occurred recently have started to serve as a platform for this new surge (no pun intended) in electric vehicle interests. While naysayers do point to the heavy metals used in the production of these giant Li-Ion batteries, there will be a much cheaper means of storing all of that energy, and charging far more rapidly in the years to come, which so also happens to be more ecologically friendly.

Graphene/Carbon nanotubes are a crystalline structure, that when aligned correctly, can accumulate a charge much more rapidly than your traditional Li-Ion batteries. Graphene can also be grown from a very diverse range of organic materials and recycled materials. Carbon nanotubes can be grown as well.

http://phys.org/news/2015-08-scientists-high-quality-graphene-tea-tree.html

By using biomass sources, carbon nanotubes are technically renewable resources, and can be grown at room temperature, both in a vacuum and at normal atmospheric pressure.

http://cleantechnica.com/2014/05/12/new-graphene-carbon-nanotube-supercapacitor/

+shamp00p The two terms are synonymous. An engine is defined as a device that converts energy into mechanical energy. An electric motor meets this definition, therefore, there is absolutely nothing wrong with calling it an engine. 
If you wan't to get nit-picky about the word, complain about search engines. There is no mechanical motion involved so they don't meet the requirement.

text: It's a good forecast attempt but not complete enough. Where do all these cars get the electricity from? Does the electricity come from wind, solar, coal, fossil fuel etc??? When the electrical cars get old, no longer driveable how do we recycle the batteries? Are these going to be lithium? We are so much in the infancy phase
author: Jahspecs1

text:
+Jahspecs1 - There are answers to all of those questions with a bit of Googling. 

1) Power stations are WAY more efficient than internal combustion engines, so powering an electric car on energy produced in a coal power station will still be about twice as efficient as a gasoline car. But electrics can be powered on anything. Get some solar panels on your roof or get your energy from an eco energy company (in the UK we have a few) and you're driving with zero (or close to it) running footprint (but you still have a bit of manufacturing footprint). Here's one of many people's attempts to quantify the long-term environmental benefits of EVs over ICE cars: http://shrinkthatfootprint.com/electric-cars-green

2) Tesla's batteries are virtually 100% recyclable - https://www.teslamotors.com/en_GB/blog/teslas-closed-loop-battery-recycling-program

The trick when thinking about EVs and making them as efficient as possible is to remember that our power grid can draw power from many different sources, so it's up to us to give our money to providers who contribute to the national grid using renewables. This is how we change the world. Your DOLLARS are your votes. Change the infrastructure and you change the world. Questioning the point of EVs because they still draw power from coal burning power stations leads to one conclusion: the future needs fewer coal burning power stations. Make it happen.
author: Dan Paveley

text: +Dan Paveley Electric cars are AWESOME, but this forecast by the video is a bit naive. Disrupting the oil market can have disastrous consequences. There is a reason why oil is known as the "Black Gold". Oil is not just used in cars. It is also used in medicine, transporting of goods (think of big trucks, planes and huge cargo ships that cannot be easily replaced by electric motors), mining, farming, fertilizer, manufacturing of essential chemicals, and the list goes on. Disrupting oil means disrupting those industries. A power station may be more efficient, but the transport of large amount of current is not feasible economically (look up demand costs and cost upgrading electric infrastructure). A solution that keeps getting thrown around is solar panels. Solar panels are great in theory, but only in theory.  Solar panels have a limitations placed by their materials. (Of course people are trying to think of unique ideas to break through these limits.) In the grand scheme of things, putting solar panels on everything does not solve our energy needs. There are too many constraints and it's not a good economical solution (the costs are too high). (I'll let google give you a more complete solution.) I think electric cars have a future, but I also think oil will be with us for a long long long time.
author: Neuroguy100

text: +Neuroguy100 Well, at the very least the pollution can be lessened, and the oil supply for cars can be shifted for other usage, like the ones you mentioned above :) a very very naive comment, I know
author: Rayhan Baradi Pratama

text:
@Neuroguy100  I know, we still have a lot of work to do as a species and switching cars to electrics is only a very small piece of the pie. The big one is getting off meat (at least 'real' meat) as animal agriculture has the biggest footprint of anything we do, requires acres of rainforest to be destroyed every minute, consumes about half of the food we grow worldwide, half the medicine we make, half the water we have access to, and is just inherently and systematically cruel.

Switching planes to electric is also tricky but not impossible. Elon Musk talks often about a project he's planning for a vertical take-off and landing electric passenger jet. Hopefully he'll start on that in about ten years' time once everything's ticking over at Tesla and SpaceX.

Ships are also not going to be easy, but it's not impossible. Here's a project the US Navy is nearly finished on which will lead to other things: http://cleantechnica.com/2013/11/05/us-navy-launches-new-all-electric-zumwalt-destroyer/

And lastly, there's biofuel. By growing the plant and then harvesting it and burning it there is actually virtually zero carbon footprint. I know that seems silly when you're clearly burning diesel and releasing CO2, but it doesn't matter if the CO2 was sequestered a month ago rather than millions of years ago. The problem with fossil fuels is that we're burning millions of years' build-up all at once. Biofuel totally negates that problem. 


Bosch are doing away with all engine-powered tools and making everything electric including lawn mowers, chainsaws, hedge trimmers etc. The result is a quieter machine that lasts way longer and doesn't require oil for lubrication. This whole idea that we'll always need fossil fuels to lubricate things is silly because the main things that need lubrication are of course engines, which disappear when you convert to electric. The few things that still need oil can easily use synthetic. In fact, you probably have synthetic (not fossil) oil lubricating your car's engine right now and don't know it.

Lego are going totally green and if they can do it so can other plastics manufacturers. 

In terms of infrastructure, no one is saying it's going to be easy but it's still going to happen. Look at Tesla's supercharger network. If you proposed that in the YouTube comments section ten years ago you'd have been laughed at. Nuclear fusion is becoming a very realistic possibility (China managed it for 102 seconds two weeks ago). My money's riding on that.

author: Sean Mullane

text:
+Sean Mullane here are a few things to consider:  
1. Power plants are far more efficient energy generators than combustion engines, even considering substantial transmission losses
2. Petroleum requires a large transportation infrastructure just to move the fuel around; 
3. In contrast to a large fuel transportation network; electric vehicles can simply harvest new energy from the sun, or from a local charging station that is replenished by the sun.

text: Why does everyone seem to believe that all oil produced goes into cars? A lot of that oil goes into materials, products, and energy generation.  Anyway, here's the deal; I fuel up once a month. I stand there for five minutes and I can go 500+ miles on that. I refuel for another 5 minutes and I'm off again for another full 500 if I want. Until electric cars can do a 5 min full recharge, they won't be more than a market niche filler. What you need is an automated system. Like an automatic car wash where a robotic arm removes a spent battery bank from the underside of the car and replaces it with a charged one. You wouldn't even need to get out of your car.
author: VirtualSuperSoldier

text: +VirtualSuperSoldier Tesla has been doing tests on battery swaps for some time, but it really isn't going to be that important in the long run. Most people use their cars for driving to work every day, not long range stuff. So when you can charge the car overnight in your own garage without even having to be there, then that 5 mins at the pump is more of a count against gas, rather than for it. Gas cars have to go to a gas station to refuel, while EVs can charge anywhere there is electric. For most uses, that makes EVs more convenient.

author: Don Weidner

text:
+Xellos Metallium The problem is that there isn't enough surface area on the car to recover the power needed to run a car. It isn't a limitation of solar panels, the sun only puts out so much energy at a time. It is a bit over 1kwh per square meter. Assuming the hood and the roof are covered you might get 3kwh of charging. Teslas get about 3 miles per kwh so even if you can convert ALL of the energy coming into the solar panals from the sun into forward motion, you would only be able to travel 9 miles per hour. This assumes perfect energy conversion and 100% efficiency of the system, which will never happen. 

https://forums.teslamotors.com/forum/forums/miles-kwh

text:
I love how everyone on here is 'screw big oil!!'.  All of your favorite devices are made by Oil byproducts. Your TV's, Ipads, Cellphones, Computers, Stereos, Mp3 players, Video Game consoles and legions of other things.  There is no replacement for plastic.  Unless you want to have a TV made out of rubber or wood?

Don't be so stupid and hypocritical.  You don't get to curse big oil knowing that you consume it.  Whether you drive, or play an X Box - you contribute to consumption.

Secondly, the effect on power grid would be enormous.  You would need to build a fleet of nuclear reactors in the US to meet the demand of the energy grid if people were charging cars 24 hours a day.  Windmills won't do the job, they barely produce a fraction of what you would need.  Solar is great and all, but still not enough or remotely close.

Coal? We are getting out of using coal.  We would have to switch to clean coal, which would also come at a steep price.  And finally? Your hydro bill would go through the roof. Not to mention there would massive amounts of unemployment related to it.

We created the Oil beast, we can't tame it.

text:
I do know people that have been able to power their homes and electric cars strictly with the solar panels they've placed on their roofs.  When they have a surplus the electric company actually buys it from them. 

We haven't done solar on our house in Chicago but I can say the electric bill impact our Nissan Leaf and BMW i3 have had have been very negligible. More and more plugins have been sold in this region and so far so good with our power grid. In fact, with time of use rates our electricity can go down to about $0.02/kWh and our EVs can go 5 miles with 1 kWh. It takes 6 kwh to refine a gallon of gasoline. Also a gallon of gas at .... Let's say $3.00/gallon to go 30 miles costs a lot more than 0.12 worth of electricity to go 30 miles. The cost of the lease completely displaced the former payment and gas costs. 

That said absolutely correct, many products we purchase are derived from fossil fuels but there's no reason not to lessen that.

author: Robert Johnson

text:
You don't know the future any more than I do; it's far too early to make big declarative statements like that about hydrogen.  I don't see solar and wind taking off in North America anymore than hydrogen fuel cells.  And even if they do, those are far outside the expertise of a petrochemical company.  They might as well get into the drywall business at that point.

As for the biofuels, not all of the good ones are alcohol.  Algae fuels are actually oil based and much more like "real" petroleum.  That's good because you can use it in a 1966 Ford truck without destroying the fuel system like alcohol does.  It also means you could conceivably make carbon neutral plastics and other petrochemicals.
author: JETZcorp

text:
I don't need to see the future to understand the science behind fuel cell cars, its a matter of allowing hydrogen atoms to combine with oxygen atoms which causes them to shed one of their electrons. The process of making hydrogen fuel requires large amounts of initial energy input, and you can only extract a fraction of that energy within the vehicle. Its only being sold as green because the only emissions you get from the process are water, but its a dirty fuel in its production phase. 

Solar power is actually booming right now, there are more jobs being created for solar than there are for oil, and the price just keeps coming down, so rest assured, in a decade or less you'll see solar become a major competitor for energy production.

http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2014/06/07/why-hydrogen-fuel-cells-have-no-future.aspx

http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/solar-power-sees-unprecedented-boom-in-u-s/

author: Wubb8t

text:
We leased a Nissan Leaf as an experiment to replace our aging but paid off Mercedes. The lease payment was about 250/mo with a very negligible electric bill increase. So the lease replaced our gasoline costs per month.  When that lease was up a month ago we purchased a BMW i3 as a replacement. 

Majority (97%) of the time we are only charging in our garage at home. The range is more than sufficient for our needs.  When we have needed to get a charge elsewhere we've been able to build them into that trip  plenty of rest stops and restaurants in Chicago and suburbs have chargers right in the parking lot. Check Plugshare for chargers in your own area.
author: Derek G. Weber

text:
Oh as for batteries ....   Nissan had an interesting track record for battery reliability between 2011 and 2012 due to the battery chemistry they used and a lack of a decent cooling system.   We had a 2013 in Chicago with no range loss.   2015 brought an even better pack.  It's warranties for 8 years regardless.  Our BMW i3 has a much better thermal management system and I'm sure the next Leaf will also.  

As for the Chevrolet Volt they have a good thermal management system and I've not heard of anyone needing replacements in the forums.   There's a few high mileage members with 200k miles on their cars already with no capacity loss.
author: Derek G. Weber

author: naruto00nix

text:
A hortatory piece of rhetoric, but the trend is somewhat away from oil and this will continue into a 'lazy' S curve over a much longer period of time.  At issue is the 'breakthrough' that will overcome the limitations of electric vehicles, which are principally related to the amount of energy that can be stored onboard and the time to recharge.  While popularly-priced electric vehicles will soon be common, their limitations make them unsuitable for a principal or sole vehicle choice.  Still it's extremely odd that light duty, daytime delivery vehicles such as the familiar droning Post Office trucks aren't being replaced with an all-out electric effort by a government owner who can't wait to get the populace into electrics.

Another area of concern in the video is the depiction of windmills, solar panels and hydroelectric dams powering all of the forecast EV's.  I guess all winter, in calm weather and at night, there won't be recharging going on--or is the video mostly BS?  Energy isn't a question of hype, it's a question of generation and distribution planning alongside a realistic appraisal of existing and likely population patterns.  Bad policy has led to urban sprawl and the according congestion and wasteful energy use it brings. Is improvement imminent?

text:
+mike salami 
+Dragon029 
Don't forget nuclear. While it's part of the grid already (USA uses about 20% and France around 70%), these designs are really, really old water-cooled designs from the the 60s. Newer and significantly different designs are being built for the first time in generations that show a HUGE improvement in every imaginable way. Look up Liquid Fluoride Reactor. Uses thorium (4 times as abundant as Uranium in nature), nearly a hundred times more energy produced per ounce, vastly more safe - no pressurization whatsoever, chemical moderation that keeps temperatures below a certain level naturally rather than human oversight, no water involved in the design that can make a steam explosion, etc. Not to mentioned a giant reduction of waste, that decays to safe levels within a few hundred years, as opposed to tens of thousands. And zero carbon emissions.

text:
For all the naysayers out there. Industries have to adapt to the changing technological paradigm or die, it's been like that since the wheelbarrow. There is no other way. We can't keep the gas car for the sake of the oil industry, it will never happen. 

Years ago people had ice delivered to their houses. A delivery guy literally brought huge blocks of ice to your house for your "ice box" to keep your food cold. Then they invented the refrigerator. It's asinine to have argued that we need to keep ice boxes, otherwise the ice delivery companies would go under. 

Sure it's more complicated with gas/oil. For example the US dollar, the worlds currency, is basically backed by oil. Blame those with lack of insight for that, a paradigm shift is happening. Basing your economy on something that is going to take a nosedive sooner rather than later is short sighted. Those with foresight will benefit from that, those who can't see it will not. It's really as simple as that.

In addition, lithium is not the only rare earth metal being consumed. There is Antimony (#62),¬†Tellurium (#70), Platinum, (#71),¬†and Gold (#72). I would rather not waste them on shitty solar panels and wind turbines that will never be able to provide for the energy demands of a country. text: People said the same of mobile computing.. the expense for wireless connectivity and mobile computing would be only available to the Uber rich.... Now look today...everything is connected.. free WiFi is everywhere and expected to be everywhere. So How did WiFi connectivity become Free?? It turns out if you offer it they will come. To your Mall ..your Coffee shop ..your Restaurant..your Hotel.. your Bank. Free WiFi = more sales. Now you say where are you going to plug in your electric car?? text:
Re energy production, what you are not taking into account is the storage ability of EV's, & the off peak generating capacity of existing power stations.  Currently power stations are geared around peak consumption, which is where the limited buffer you mentioned comes in.  EV's can actually increase the buffer by providing storage (e.g. connected to grid, or power a house), + they can be programmed to charge in off peak periods.  Some calculations show that with EV's, there is actually no need to build any new power stations in the UK for at least 20-30 years!

Re tax.  You can try to increase tax revenue by other means, or maybe better to reduce costs.  There are plenty of costs incurred with the gas cars that need to be recovered by taxes.  These include the direct costs such as traffic, health, climate, water pollution, air pollution, noise pollution, crashes, & indirect costs such as $Trillion war in the middle east securing oil assets.

author: PhysicsBasics

text:
richystar2001 
There is no such thing as free WiFi. Wifi in malls and coffee shops,  hotels,  etc., is paid for by selling the data that the network is acquiring from your device while using their "free" wifi. 
Also, who is going to pay for all the electricity these cars require while parked at the hotel, restaurant, etc.? It must come with a higher cost for your hotel room or your dinner plate. There must be a larger power grid and infrastructure to accomodate such a crazy power hunger.
Also, powering something with just electricity isn't always efficient. It may work for small cars, but no so much for utility vehicles, semi-trucks, and construction equipment. Even electrical motors on board of locomotives are powered by diesel generators (unless the train is on a power line). 
Electricity is not always efficient. Consider the water heater in your house: it's a lot more efficient to use a gas heater than an electric heater. This is why in cold places, you hardly find electric heaters. Everything is heated with gas, oil, or wood.
Better than fossil fuels or wood is nuclear power, but I doubt that will get into your car very soon.

text:
Yay electric cars! That and automated cars are going to be awesome. But the beginning of the video is incorrect!
The video is incorrect in its definition of peak oil.  We aren't running out of oil, rather, we're running out of economically viable oil which prevents us from increasing production. This means as the price of oil goes up, a lot of oil stores that were once too expensive now become economically viable.  

For example, the Canadian oil sands were found in the 1920's but was too expensive to extract at the time.

In other words, we have a LOT of oil left, but the costs to extract it grow exponentially.
author: jinudave

text: +jinudave That's really moving the goalposts.  A few years ago peak oil folks were not predicting production increases at all.  They were saying that large increases in production would require more energy than it would produce, so couldn't ever happen economically, regardless of the price of oil.  They didn't count on a technological revolution like fracking that dramatically increases production without proportionate increase in energy input.  Look at the graph of US oil production over the last few years.  It isn't anything close to a bell curve, as predicted by peak oil theory.

text:
okay, because you're obnoxiously ignorant, here are 3 simple differences for both fuel cells and batteries that even Mr.Fact "their the same" can understand. I hope that you're fuming anger doesn't cause you to continue making yourself look bad.

For a battery:
1. The electrodes dissolve in the chemical reaction. ¬†When they‚Äôre gone, the battery is dead.
2. The amount of energy the battery supplies is determined by the amount of chemicals in the battery (‚ÄòD‚Äô cells last longer than ‚ÄòAAA‚Äô cells).
3. In some cases (re-chargeable batteries), the chemicals can be restored by reversing the current and restoring the original chemicals, but over time the chemicals will eventually lose this capacity.

For a Fuel Cell:
1. The electrodes are not consumed: As long as fuel is supplied, the cell will generate a voltage: it won‚Äôt ‚Äòrun down‚Äô.
2. The amount of energy is determined by the amount of gas reactants. (Same as liquid reactants for a combustion engine).
3. It can supply energy continuously (like a combustion engine).

IF YOU ARE ARE STILL COMMITTED TO IGNORANCE: This article from the "World Academy of Science, Engineering and Technology Volume 26" it goes over all of the pro/con differences between both technologies. You'll notice that their compare Fuel Cells to petroleum fuels at times.¬†http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.79.4690&rep=rep1&type=pdf

author: N A

text:
+David Foster I'm going to stop you right where you claimed batteries are 'tossed in the trash'.  Clearly you know very, very little about the battery market, so please, just stop talking. 

Hint:  Automotive batteries are sodding recycled or given a second-life.  There's too many  rare materials in EV batteries for any sane businessman to just 'throw them in the trash'.  The current 18650 cells Panasonic and LG chem are providing for most of the EV industry are designed to be, for the most part, recycled and/or repurposed when they reach vehicle EoL (end of life), which, given the current cell performance we're seeing in existing EVs today, can easily last the vehicle's typical lifetime.

Oh, and hydrogen fuel cell cars ARE electric cars.  It's also a kind of electric car. It runs on a motor powered by electricity. What makes it different from a battery-electric vehicle (or BEV) is where the electricity comes from. Instead of a battery, a hydrogen fuel cell car generates its power ON-BOARD from the fuel cell.  

This is the primary reason why a hydrogen fuel cell car is an electric car:  The fuel cell generates electricity, which is then excess-stored in an on-board battery or used to directly power the wheels via use of a DC or AC motor.  So, just like a battery-car the drivetrain is the same; an electric motor.  The only difference is you're generating that electricity on-site instead of at a power station (or solar panels).  If it runs on electricity, it's electric.  It's that simple.

Gasoline cars, on the other hand, are not electric. Your comment "With that logic anything which has an electric motor would be an electric car including Gas" is utterly moronic because, quite simply, that's not how gasoline cars work.  They don't HAVE an electric motor to drive the wheels.  The energy propulsion that drives the shaft, transmission and in turn powers the wheels is generated by combustion occurring in the engine cylinders.  Gas cars, simply put, do not use an electric motor at all.  The thrust (the driving motion) is generated as a result of miniature internal explosions that happen at a high frequency within the engine.  This is generating motion through combustion directly.  Now yes, some of that energy does go to the vehicle's inverter, but that only helps power the car's electrical systems such as the radio and headlights.  The actual powertrain for the wheels is 100% powered by burning fuel.

Perhaps the biggest failing of your entire logic is how you speak in the present:  How the cars currently require X sized batteries or Y materials.  Why else do you think scientists are working to develop better solutions?  If people like you ran the world, technology would hardly progress because you would always consider things in terms of the 'here and now' instead of the 'where they could be in the future'.

Ever heard the saying "Rome wasn't built in a day"?
Also ever heard the saying "you're a fucking clueless idiot and should stop talking about things you know next to nothing about?"

I am only opposed to modern battery based cars not where it could be in the future. The amount of CO2 being mitigated is small compared to the environmental damage produced in the production and disposal of modern batteries + the supermajority of electric sources to recharge these batteries are fossil fuel based. There will be an increase in mining/drilling for batteries for powering and making them given the current energy infrastructure. Hydrogen fuel cells would require a far less impact on the environment in the production, use, and disposal.

The main argument is that Hydrogen Fuel Cells = Electric Cars. I say that's false. There are a multitude of differences between them!

text: Well, hydro is tunable - pull from solar during the day and build up your reservoirs, then open the gates and use hydro at night for example.  But we're still pretty far from that, it will be a good problem to have if we get renewable sources to the point we need to store it.  Also if we can make more energy than demand then we won't need to store it at all.
